image_1.context: The ‘What am I to do?’ exclaimed Alice, looking about in great perplexity, as first one round head, and then the other, rolled down from her shoulder, and lay like a heavy lump in her lap. ‘I don’t think it ever happened before, that any one had to take care of two Queens asleep at once! No, not in all the History of England––it couldn’t, you know, because there never was more than one Queen at a time. Do wake up, you heavy things!’ she went on in an impatient tone; but there was no answer but a gentle snoring. Alice, as she tried to obey the first direction: ‘and I don’t know any soothing lullabies.’ ‘I must do it myself, then,’ said the Red Queen, and she began:–– ‘Hush-a-by lady,\* in Alice’s lap! Till the feast’s ready, we’ve time for a nap. When the feast’s over, we’ll go to the ball–– Red Queen, and White Queen, and Alice, and all! ‘And now you know the words,’ she added, as she put her head down on Alice’s other shoulder, ‘just sing it through to me. I’m getting sleepy, too.’ In another moment both Queens were fast asleep, and snoring loud.
image_1.description: The image is a black-and-white illustration depicting a whimsical scene from the story of Alice in Wonderland. At the center, Alice stands with a surprised and somewhat bewildered expression, wearing a dress and a crown, holding a scepter. On either side of her are two large, round-headed figures resembling queens, each adorned with crowns and dressed in elaborate clothing. The queen on the left appears to be asleep, leaning heavily against Alice, while the queen on the right is also slumped over, contributing to the sense of weight and burden that Alice seems to be carrying. The background features tall grasses and wildflowers, adding to the fantastical and dreamlike atmosphere of the scene. The overall mood conveyed is one of confusion and absurdity, as Alice finds herself in an unexpected and surreal situation.

image_2.image_path: ./fusion_research/fusion_dataset/novel/Alices Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass (Lewis Carroll) (5)/images/image_2.jpg
image_2.context: ‘Shouldn’t do that––shouldn’t do ‘Nothing!’ Alice said impatiently. ‘I’ve been knocking at it!’ ‘I speaks English, doesn’t I?’ the Frog went on. ‘Or are you deaf? What did it ask you?’ ‘I don’t know what you mean,’ she said. ‘To answer the door?’ he said. ‘What’s it been asking of?’ He was so hoarse that Alice could scarcely hear him. The Frog looked at the door with his large dull eyes for a minute: then he went nearer and rubbed it with his thumb, as if he were trying whether the paint would come off: then he looked at Alice. a bang. Alice knocked and rang in vain for a long time; but at last a very old Frog, who was sitting under a tree, got up and hobbled slowly towards her: he was dressed in bright yellow, and had enormous boots on. ‘What is it, now?’ the Frog said in a deep hoarse whisper. Alice turned round, ready to find fault with anybody. ‘Where’s the servant whose business it is to answer the door?’ she began angrily. ‘Which door?’ said the Frog. Alice almost stamped with irritation at the slow drawl in which he spoke. ‘This door, of course!’
image_2.description: The image is a black-and-white illustration depicting a scene from the story of Alice in Wonderland. The main characters are Alice and a frog-like creature. Alice, dressed in a Victorian-style dress with a crown on her head, stands to the right of the image. She appears to be speaking or shouting at the door, which has an inscription above it reading 'Queen Alice.' The door is ornate with intricate designs and a knocker shaped like a frog's head. To the left of the door stands a frog-like creature, dressed in a bright yellow outfit with large boots, holding a cane. The creature has a solemn expression and is looking towards Alice. The background features a detailed archway with decorative patterns. The overall atmosphere conveys a sense of frustration and confusion, as Alice tries to get the door opened while the frog-like creature seems indifferent or slow to respond.

image_3.context: cut any one you’ve been introduced to. Remove the joint!’ And the waiters carried it ‘Certainly not,’ the Red Queen said, very decidedly: ‘it isn’t etiquette to ‘You look a little shy: let me introduce you to that leg of mutton,’ said the Red Queen. ‘Alice Mutton: Mutton— Alice.’\* The leg of mutton got up in the dish and made a little bow to Alice; and Alice returned the bow, not knowing whether to be frightened or amused. ‘May I give you a slice?’ she said, taking up the knife and fork, and looking from one Queen to the other. ‘I should never have known who were the right people to invite!’ There were three chairs at the head of the table: the Red and White Queens had already taken two of them, but the middle one was empty. Alice sat down in it, rather uncomfortable at the silence, and longing for some one to speak. At last the Red Queen began. ‘You’ve missed the soup and fish,’ she said. ‘Put on the joint!’ And the waiters set a leg of mutton before Alice, who looked at it rather anxiously, as she had never had to carve a joint before.
image_3.description: The image is a black-and-white illustration depicting a whimsical and surreal scene. The main figure appears to be a leg of mutton, which is anthropomorphized with a head and arms. The leg of mutton is standing on a plate, wearing what looks like a hat or a flower on its head, and it has a somewhat dignified posture. It is holding a small object in one hand, possibly a napkin or a piece of paper. The background is abstract, with indistinct shapes and lines that suggest a chaotic or dreamlike setting. The overall atmosphere is one of absurdity and fantasy, fitting the context of a story where food items come to life and interact with human characters.

The cat appears to be a raccoon-like creature with a striped tail. To the right of Alice, there is another cat sitting on the ground, looking up at her with a curious expression.
